M_0030_12y1m_2.wav.transcription: Off you go. Right, I'm going to talk about one of my hobbies, which is making polyhedra. The word polyhedra comes from the Greek. The first half of it means many, and next means faces, so it means many faces, literally. The last one I've made is a rhombocube octahedron, which is like a cube, only it's got some triangles on all the corners, and it's evened out, no sharp points. Before that, I made a dodecahedron, dodeca meaning 12 hedron faces again, which is different from a dodecagon, which is only 2D shaped with 12 sides. And they do actually look quite different. I started this in the summer holidays last year when I got bored. All you really need is a piece of cardboard from a cereal packet, a pencil, ruler, protractor, pencil sharpener, razor maybe. One of the first ones I made was a basic cube. And you just put flaps everywhere and then join them up with the glue. After that I started making up my own shapes which didn't always work. I once made like a cross like that and it had a piece in the middle. It's like a 3D cross. And that almost turned out right. But I think it's a physical impossibility because you don't have enough area on the card, so you'd have to make it more than one piece. So the aim is to always make these out of single sheets? I do my best. Sometimes I have to use more than one, like in that case. But I didn't know them because I just made it up.

M_1064_47y0m_1.wav.transcription: I presume you want to cut this off. of them we discussed already but it doesn't matter. You started telling me about your opinion about the CityLate course, what you felt and I understood also that you started feeling a lot of different things when you came. Yeah, I could read that article there a lot easier. As I said, before I came on this course I would never have read that. I would have made any excuse rather than read out loud, you know, to anybody, even my wife. I will not read out loud. I just refuse to do it. So I do feel a lot easier now about my attitude to speech and my attitude to my speech. I'm not as aware, I think, as I was before. It's good. It's very, very good. Tell me, what is your actual job? I work as a production controller on and off the oil platform. That means I control everything that goes on onboard the oil platform. How much oil we bring onboard, how much of everything, all the control actions that are required, that's what I do. So you're actually on the board all the time, it's a ship, it's a big... When I say on board, that's just a nautical expression, it doesn't move, it's nailed into the seabed, it doesn't move. I've always worked in the oil industry, ever since I was 18, so it's just another... It's the same as I've always done, really. Except I've not always worked with oil, directly with oil, which I do now. It's always been in the associated industries. And sort of all the offshoots you get from the oil industry. The gas and chemicals and various things. I'm willing to continue it. I work away from home. I work away for 14 days, then I'm home for 14 days. I'm reasonably happy doing it, as happy as, I suppose, any job. It's hard going away from home. But once I actually get into work, it's OK. But it's just hard to get there. But what does it say? Once I'm there, I'm there. Like we had in the army. Probably. Was you in the army? Yeah. Oh, of course, yeah. So we also went for 14 days and then came home for a weekend and went again. It's hard going back, isn't it? Yeah, it's very hard. But once you're back, it's okay. Yeah. It's the same with me. I can remember this feeling. And you're married, you have kids also? Yeah, I'm married. I have three daughters. Do you want their ages? Yeah. Age 13. She was just 13 this month. One's 11 and the other one, she's 9. That's it. And you have brothers, sisters? I have three brothers, yeah? And you are the oldest? And tell me, was there someone in your family that you know of, you've heard in the history, that you used to stutter? And you know a you know, you had therapy before? I went, I imagine when I was about eight years old, up to about 14. And just about half an hour a week. And when I got to 14, she said, that's it, you're discharged. And she'd not done anything for me. I think now, in retrospect, I think, you see, when I was eight, I didn't know I had a stammer. I've no doubt my mother noticed it, and in school they must have noticed it. But I never noticed it until I got to secondary school age, which is 11. When I went to secondary school, it just hit me all of a sudden. It was, I don't know, it was just like an overnight thing. Now, I don't know why, because the school was in the area where I lived, so it was not unfamiliar. I knew boys who went to the school, so I wasn't on my own, you know. I don't know why. It all hit me within the first week of going to secondary school. And it was a school that I wanted to go to. It was not sort of enforced on me. I wanted to go to that school. I don't know why. It just hit me all in one week. One week I could speak. I was absolutely unconcerned about my speech. And the next week I could hardly speak. Very interesting. Yeah. So the whole pattern of speech change immediately? say up to going to that school I would read out in the class I would do anything the moment went to this school I would know I couldn't answer my name I couldn't repeat my name I don't know why I really don't know I've analyzed this and over and over again nothing happened at home we didn't we didn't move house okay we didn't move going, it's it called, they have an association or something. I've forgotten the name of it. They have some national association with stammerers. Well, it wasn't advertised. It had an article on TV on the local news. Like about half past six in the evening you have a local news. And they just happened to mention this and there's an interview of the leader of this association. They said they're having a meeting in Manchester. Well, I live near Manchester anyway. It was on the following day, so I went into Manchester, heard what they had to say, and then they referred me. They asked for all our names if we'd not had a therapy, had any therapy. I was referred to a speech therapist near me. She heard me. She said, I don't think you have a stammer because of all my avoidance. I said, well, I can assure you I have got one. And she said, well, I will refer you off to this place.
